stem: A client with heart failure reports sharp chest pain on inspiration and a dry cough. Physical exam reveals dullness on percussion and absent breath sounds at the right lung base. Complete the clinical bowtie.

actions.text: Position the client leaning forward over a bedside table

rationale.correct: Effusions in heart failure are often transudative, caused by increased hydrostatic pressure and decreased oncotic pressure (c1, c2). Actions include preparing for thoracentesis (a1) and positioning (a2) to facilitate the procedure. Monitoring respiratory rate, symmetry, and post-procedure breath sounds (p1, p2) is crucial to assess for complications and effectiveness of treatment.
rationale.incorrect: Postural drainage is used for mobilizing secretions, not pleural fluid. While oxygen may be supportive, it does not address the underlying cause or remove the fluid.

clinicalPearls: Dullness on percussion indicates the presence of fluid or a solid mass, while hyperresonance suggests the presence of air.
Transudative pleural effusions are often caused by increased hydrostatic pressure or decreased oncotic pressure, as seen in heart failure and liver cirrhosis.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: While pneumonia can cause pleural effusion, the context of heart failure suggests a transudative effusion due to pressure imbalances. Consider the underlying condition when interpreting clinical findings.

mnemonic.title: PLEURA
mnemonic.expansion:
P - Position client leaning forward
L - Lung sounds (monitor)
E - Effusion (suspect)
U - Underlying cause (identify)
R - Respiratory rate (monitor)
A - Aspirate fluid (thoracentesis)

reviewUnits.heading: Pleural Effusion
reviewUnits.body: Pleural effusion is an abnormal accumulation of fluid in the pleural space, the area between the lungs and the chest wall. It can be caused by a variety of conditions, including heart failure, pneumonia, and cancer.
